  \cellcolor{green!5}\small I'll admit, I was pretty spoiled growing up in the sense I usually got what I wanted EVENTUALLY. Like, I might say, "Mom, I really, really want a Gameboy. Can I get one? Please?" in like May or June, and I'd get it for either Christmas or my birthday (which is February, typically right after my mother got her tax return). But, I almost never got something expensive right there on the spot (unless it was new shoes, which I burned through like \textbf{crazy} as a child, and I admittedly always wore expensive shoes because of a broken foot/ankle I received in the womb when I lodged my foot into my mother's ribs and it had to be maneuvered back out, which meant had had to have very high topped shoes in my early childhood for support so my ankle didn't collapse). Even at Christmas, I knew that my mother was paying for the gifts, not Santa. (She told me Santa picked them up from layaway and delivered them, but she had to pay for them.) I never wanted for anything, but I knew where the money came from and was never a tantrum throwing \textbf{brat} when I was told we couldn't get something.
